items.title: AI-driven weather prediction breakthrough reported
items.author: Dr. Anna Allen, Richard Turner, Dr. Scott Hosking
items.summary:
- New AI weather prediction method by Aardvark Weather is significantly faster and more efficient than traditional systems.
- The approach allows a single researcher with a desktop computer to provide accurate forecasts using raw data from various sources globally.
- The findings published in Nature suggest improvements in forecast speed, accuracy, and cost, and the model may produce accurate eight-day forecasts and hyper-local predictions.
- The method can democratize forecasting for developing nations and improve predictions for natural disasters and climatic issues.
- Aardvark could outperform the US national GFS forecasting system using only 10% of the data that existing systems require.

items.title: Australian government agencies could be customers of Israeli spyware, research suggests
items.summary:
- Australian agencies may be customers of Israeli spyware from Paragon Solutions according to a new report.
- In January, Meta reported over 90 individuals had their WhatsApp accounts compromised, raising concerns about potential Australian targets.
- The Citizen Lab identified two IP addresses in Australia linked to Paragon's Graphite spyware, suggesting possible use by government agencies.
- Paragon’s software provides full access to messaging apps and is exclusively sold to governments, not private enterprises.
- Australian government departments, including Home Affairs and the Signals Directorate, reportedly have no connections to Paragon Solutions.
- Paragon's executive chairman emphasized compliance with laws and regulations in their operations.

items.title: Labour Reconsiders Smartphone Ban in Schools as Pressure Grows Over Effect on Teenagers
items.author: Bridget Phillipson
items.summary:
- Education Secretary Bridget Phillipson will reevaluate smartphone bans in schools due to concerns from MPs about social media effects on teens.
- A monitoring initiative will be launched to assess compliance and effectiveness of existing guidance on smartphone usage in schools.
- Current guidelines prohibit mobile phone use throughout the school day but lack enforcement measures.
- A focus on behavior and impact of policies will inform future National Behaviour Surveys.
- Public sentiment is leaning towards a complete smartphone ban, with a notable portion of parents expressing dissatisfaction with the current policy.

items.title: Tesla backer says Musk must reduce Trump work, as 46,000 Cybertrucks recalled
items.summary:
- Tesla announces a recall of 46,000 Cybertrucks to fix an exterior panel issue.
- Protests are planned globally on 29 March, with 500 demonstrations against Tesla.
- Tesla shares have lost one-third of their value over recent investor concerns, including Musk's involvement with Trump.
- Dan Ives from Wedbush warns Musk needs to balance his roles at Tesla and Doge to prevent brand damage.
- The recall relates to a cant rail, which can detach and pose a road hazard; replacements will be provided free of charge.

items.title: Nvidia will spend hundreds of billions on US manufacturing, says CEO
items.author: Jensen Huang
items.summary:
- Nvidia plans to invest several hundred billion dollars in US semiconductor and electronics manufacturing over the next four years.
- CEO Jensen Huang cites unpredictable tariff threats as a reason for reshaping the supply chain away from Asia.
- The company's value has surged to $2.9 trillion due to the AI market boom, increasing reliance on Taiwanese chipmakers is seen as risky.
- Huang expresses confidence in the US manufacturing capability amidst competition from China, particularly highlighting Huawei's success.
- Recent $100 billion investment by TSMC aids Nvidia in onshoring manufacturing for its top-tier Blackwell chips, enhancing supply chain resilience.

items.title: UK watchdog bans ‘shocking’ ads in mobile games that objectified women
items.summary:
- The UK Advertising Standards Authority (ASA) banned eight ads from mobile games for depicting women in a sexualized and objectifying manner.
- Investigations utilized avatars to monitor ad compliance, revealing significant breaches of UK advertising codes.
- The banned ads portrayed harmful scenarios including non-consensual sexual situations and violent control themes.
- The ASA received a survey showing 45% of UK consumers concerned about idealized body images and 44% about the objectification of women in ads.
- The move reflects ongoing efforts by the ASA to enforce stricter rules established in 2019 regarding representation in advertising.

items.title: UK cybersecurity agency warns over risk of quantum hackers
items.summary:
- The UK’s cybersecurity agency warns organizations to guard against quantum hackers by 2035.
- The National Cyber Security Centre (NCSC) recommends implementing post-quantum cryptography for critical infrastructures like energy and transport.
- Quantum computers could potentially break current encryption methods used in banking and secure communications due to their ability to process complex calculations quickly.
- Organizations are advised to complete upgrades by 2028, with major changes by 2031 and fully migrate to new systems by 2035.
- The guidance aims to help safeguard confidential information before quantum computing capabilities are fully realized.

items.title: The Guardian view on modern masculinity: boys need mentors, not marketers | Editorial
items.summary:
- Increasingly, boys are influenced by toxic online figures promoting a hollow, misogynistic form of masculinity.
- Sir Gareth Southgate emphasizes the failure of modern society to provide young men with real-life role models and acknowledges the damaging effects of digital influences on their emotional health.
- Polls indicate that Gen Z shows heightened polarization regarding feminism and gender equality, leading to increased sexist attitudes.
- Boys today are more likely to possess smartphones than live with their fathers, causing a disconnect in community and guidance.
- There is a need for investment in families and youth programs to build resilience, empathy, and authentic relationships among boys.

items.title: Back to the feudal: Assassin’s Creed Shadows is the most beautiful game I’ve ever seen
items.summary:
- Assassin’s Creed Shadows set in 16th-century Japan, featuring historical figures like Oda Nobunaga.
- Two protagonists: Yasuke (slave turned samurai) and Naoe (peasant shinobi), offering different playstyles.
- The game is visually stunning, described as the most beautiful video game ever seen.
- Features multilingual voice options including English, Japanese, and Portuguese for a more immersive experience.
- Undertakes a serious approach to historical authenticity, moving away from the light-hearted nature of previous games in the series.
- Lacks a Discovery Tour mode similar to previous Assassin’s Creed games, but requests for its inclusion are pending.

items.title: Italian activist alerts ICC to spyware attack when in communication with court
items.author: Not given
items.summary:
- Italian activist David Yambio warned the ICC of spyware on his phone during communications about torture victims in [Libya](https://www.theguardian.com/world/libya).
- A report by The Citizen Lab confirmed Yambio was targeted by mercenary spyware during ICC communications, with attacks noted around June 2024.
- The incident raises concerns over possible government interference in ICC proceedings, particularly under Italian Prime Minister [Giorgia Meloni](https://www.theguardian.com/world/giorgia-meloni) amid scrutiny over previous surveillance claims.
- The report also noted that several activists, including friends of Pope Francis, were targeted using spyware from [Paragon Solutions](https://www.theguardian.com/business/paragongroupofcompanies).
- Investigators found evidence of spyware in WhatsApp and other apps on targeted phones, and Apple confirmed the attack's sophistication, releasing a fix in iOS 18.
- Other countries reportedly using Paragon's services include Australia, Canada, Denmark, Cyprus, Singapore, and Israel, raising concerns about the legality and oversight of such surveillance.
- EU MEP [Hannah Neumann](https://www.theguardian.com/world/europe-news) emphasized the need for stronger regulations to prevent spyware abuse.

items.title: Value of Elon Musk’s X ‘rebounds to $44bn purchase price’
items.summary:
- The value of Elon Musk’s platform X has soared back to the $44bn he purchased it for.  
- Investors valued it at $44bn in a secondary deal, a significant increase from a $10bn valuation by Fidelity in September.  
- X is attempting to raise $2bn in new equity as it faces over $1bn in junior debt.  
- Musk has faced declining revenue since acquiring the platform but reported adjusted profits of $1.2bn last year.  
- The valuation rebound is attributed to a secondary deal that will help set a price for the primary funding round.

items.title: Google to pay $28m to settle claims it favoured white and Asian employees
items.author: Not given
items.summary:
- Google has agreed to pay $28m to settle a lawsuit claiming it favored white and Asian employees over others.
- The settlement, which has preliminary approval, affects at least 6,632 employees from February 15, 2018, to December 31, 2024.
- The lawsuit was led by Ana Cantu, who alleged discriminatory practices in pay and promotions at Google, violating the California Equal Pay Act.

items.title: The Thinking Game review – DeepMind study offers wide-lens view of our tech lords and AGI
items.summary:
- The documentary provides an approachable entry into AI, focusing on DeepMind, now Google DeepMind.
- It features Demis Hassabis, DeepMind's founder, showcasing his background and achievements.
- Highlights the AI model AlphaFold, which predicts protein structures, as a significant scientific advancement.

items.title: The Best iPhones in 2025: Which Apple Smartphone is Right for You
items.summary:
- The iPhone 16 is the best choice for most users, offering a balance of features at a lower price.
- iPhone 16 Pro is recommended for photography enthusiasts with its advanced camera features.
- iPhone 16 Pro Max is ideal for those seeking the best screen and battery life.
- The cheapest new iPhone is the iPhone 16e, suitable for budget-conscious buyers.
- All models feature the latest A18 chip, supporting AI tools and improved camera capabilities.
- The iPhone 16 introduces new features like a customizable Action button and improved water resistance.

items.title: Kindle Colorsoft review: Amazon’s new e-reader gets colour screen upgrade
items.summary:
- The Kindle Colorsoft is Amazon's first e-reader with a colour screen, priced at £270.
- It offers improvements in contrast and speed over competitors like Boox and Kobo.
- Features a 7-inch colour e-paper display with 150ppi for colour and 300ppi for black & white.
- While black and white text appears a bit greyer, the functionality of the device remains solid.
- Enhanced visual organization with coloured book covers and in-text visuals, making it easier to browse.
- Supports highlighting passages in various colours, with a fast and responsive touchscreen interface.
- Battery life lasts approximately 32 hours when reading colour graphic novels.
- Weight is 219g, and dimensions are 127.6 x 176.7 x 7.8mm with IPX8 water resistance rating.
- Retains basic Kindle features with a smooth black plastic design and a single physical button.
- Although it enhances reading experiences, the small screen size makes it less ideal for full-size graphic novels.

items.title: Ban smartphones for UK under-16s, urges Adolescence writer
items.author: Jack Thorne
items.summary:
- Jack Thorne proposes that smartphones be banned for under-16s in the UK, comparing them to cigarettes.
- He emphasizes the dangers of social media algorithms that can lead teenagers to harmful online spaces.
- Thorne calls for radical government action similar to regulations in France, Norway, and Australia regarding teen access to social media.
- The Netflix show *Adolescence*, co-written by Thorne, has sparked discussions about the influence of incel culture and misogyny online.
- The show depicts a 13-year-old protagonist caught in these dangerous environments, highlighting the perception and meanings of emojis among teens.
- Academics warn about rising anti-feminist sentiments fueled by social media platforms and the need for vigilance against incel culture's symbols and language.
- The recently enacted Online Safety Act in the UK aims to control harmful content but faces challenges in identifying incel-related emojis.

items.title: Assassin’s Creed: Shadows – a historic frolic through feudal Japan
items.summary:
- Set in Japan, 1581, during the tumultuous era of Oda Nobunaga's reign.
- Combines exciting gameplay with a historical narrative as players take on the roles of a shinobi and a brave samurai.
- Features a richly detailed environment with authentic landscapes and historical settings, including Kyoto and Osaka.
- Offers dual protagonists: Fujibayashi Naoe, a stealthy female shinobi, and Yasuke, a powerful black samurai.
- Players navigate through missions that involve repetitive quest structures.
- Combat system praised for one-on-one engagements but criticized for chaotic group interactions.
- Game releases on March 20, priced at £59.99.

items.title: Russia using criminal networks to drive increase in sabotage acts, says Europol
I’m a recent Stem grad. Here’s why the right is winning us over
items.author: Jaye Chen
items.summary:
- Recent graduates in STEM feel pressure to pursue lucrative corporate roles rather than progressive careers.
- The progressive movement has failed to attract technical talent, leaving STEM graduates more conservative.
- Financial and tech industries aggressively recruit STEM students, shaping their career aspirations.
- A divide exists between the technocratic right and a disillusioned left, hindering potential collaborations.
- Progressives need to reimagine how technology can challenge power structures and recruit technical talent effectively.

items.title: The best hair straighteners for foolproof styling, tried and tested by our expert
items.author: Lise Smith
items.summary:
- The article reviews 13 hair straighteners, ranging from budget to premium models.
- **Best overall:** GHD Platinum Plus - £199 at GHD, praised for sleek design and efficiency.
- **Best budget:** Remington Shine Therapy S8500 - £29.99 at Boots, features ceramic plates infused with natural oils.
- **Best cordless:** Dyson Corrale - £399.99 at Boots, known for flexible plates and portability.
- **Best for thick hair:** GHD Max - £174, ideal for styling long or thick hair with wide plates.
- Key testing criteria included ease of use, performance, and lasting results.

items.title: Italian newspaper says it has published world’s first AI-generated edition
items.author: Claudio Cerasa
items.summary:
- Il Foglio claims to be the world's first newspaper published entirely by AI.
- The four-page edition is part of a month-long journalistic experiment.
- AI handled writing, headlines, quotes, and summaries, while journalists posed questions to the AI.
- The edition includes a story about US President Donald Trump and an article featuring Vladimir Putin.
- This initiative aims to explore AI's impact on journalism and editorial decisions.

items.title: Google’s parent to buy cybersecurity group Wiz in biggest ever deal
Crash the future: Why Musk might not make Tesla great again
items.summary:
- Elon Musk faces significant challenges as Tesla's stock has fallen 37% since the start of 2025.
- Concerns over a potential trade war and recession are impacting investor sentiment and sales.
- Protests against Musk's political involvement are increasing alongside a surge in vandalism against Tesla.
- Musk's company SpaceX experienced a rocket explosion and delay of a rescue mission for stranded astronauts.
- Outages occurred on Musk's social media platform, X, attributed to a cyberattack.
- Tesla held a sales event at the White House with Donald Trump endorsing the company, but market analysis indicates that the brand's appeal among Democrats has diminished.
- Analysts caution that the diminishing interest from Democrats could negatively impact Tesla's sales.

items.title: The story of Monolith Productions: a respected game studio's unexpected closure
items.summary:
- Warner Bros announced the closure of three game studios including Monolith Productions due to a strategic change.
- Monolith Productions was founded in 1994 and was known for its unique and unpredictable game designs.
- Some of its notable games include *Blood*, *The Operative: No One Lives Forever*, and *Middle-Earth: Shadow of Mordor*.
- The studio was recognized for its innovative gameplay features like the Nemesis system, which was patented by Warner Bros.
- Monolith had not released any new games in the last eight years before its shutdown, prompting concerns about industry practices.

items.title: Performing arts leaders issue copyright warning over UK government’s AI plans
items.summary:
- Over 30 UK performing arts leaders, including heads from National Theatre and Royal Albert Hall, express concerns over government AI plans.
- They emphasize that artists depend on copyright for their livelihoods and urge government support for creative rights.
- Signatories include executives from Sadler’s Wells, Royal Shakespeare Company, and City of Birmingham Symphony Orchestra.
- The statement criticizes the government's plan to allow AI companies to use copyrighted work without explicit consent from artists.
- Leaders call for transparency obligations on AI companies regarding the copyrighted materials used in training.
- Notable figures in the creative industries have criticized the proposals, including Sir Paul McCartney and Kate Bush.

items.title: BYD Unveils Super Fast-Charging System for Electric Vehicles
items.author: Not given
items.summary:
- BYD has announced a new super e-platform charging system capable of peak speeds of 1,000 kW.
- This technology allows EVs to charge enough to travel 400 km in just five minutes.
- The company plans to build a charging network in China and will roll out this technology in the Han L sedan and Tang L SUV.
- Charging speed will be twice that of Tesla’s superchargers, which reach up to 500 kW.
- BYD aims to alleviate 'charging anxiety' similar to petrol refueling times.
- The company will create over 4,000 ultra-fast charging units in China, though investment details are not specified.
- Tesla has seen stock declines and competition is increasing from Chinese EV manufacturers.

items.title: ‘It’s been a challenge’: Assassin’s Creed Shadows and the quest to bring feudal Japan to life
items.summary:
- Assassin’s Creed Shadows releases after four years of development and delays, set in Japan in 1579 during civil war.
- Features two protagonists: Fujibayashi Naoe, a female shinobi, and Yasuke, an African samurai.
- The game aims to authentically represent Japanese culture with in-house historians and specialists from Japan assisting in development.
- Past criticisms over the game's characters being perceived as 'woke' were addressed by emphasizing historical accuracy.
- The team conducted field trips to Kyoto and Osaka to enhance cultural detail in the game environments.
- Gameplay involves stealth and combat mechanics, focusing on historical accuracy and engaging narrative elements.

items.title: The big idea: do we worry too much about misinformation?
items.author: Adam Kucharski
items.summary:
- On 30 October 1938, a radio broadcast of HG Wells's The War of the Worlds created a panic many believed to be real, though studies show mass panic didn't occur.
- Current perceptions of misinformation may be exaggerated; for example, during Covid, visits to 'trustworthy' news sites grew dramatically, outpacing those deemed 'untrustworthy'.
- It’s important to challenge both false beliefs and the dismissal of true information without over-skepticism, as both extremes could hinder understanding and trust in media.

items.title: Telegram Founder Returns to Dubai as French Inquiry Continues
items.author: Pavel Durov
items.summary:
- Pavel Durov, founder of Telegram, returned to Dubai after leaving France where he was under investigation.
- Arrested in August at an airport near Paris, he faced charges related to criminal activity on Telegram.
- Durov spent months under investigation and was released on €5m bail, emphasizing Telegram's compliance with legal obligations.
- The French president defended granting Durov French nationality, describing it as a strategy.
- Durov received support from Elon Musk and faced allegations including child abuse and drug trafficking during his questioning.

items.title: Laughter not laptops: cafe culture fights back against keyboard invaders
items.summary:
- Cafe owners in the UK are implementing 'no laptop' policies to reclaim their spaces for social interaction.  
- Pophams Bakery has restricted laptop use, citing the need for business sustainability and community atmosphere.  
- Other cafes like Milk and Bean and Grounded have introduced similar bans, receiving mixed reactions from customers.  
- Chains like Costa and Starbucks have yet to adopt these policies, although Starbucks in North America has ended its open-door laptop usage policy.  
- The change aims to foster conversation and a more communal environment within cafes.

items.title: Nothing Phone 3a Pro review: funky mid-ranger with real zoom camera
items.summary:
- The Nothing Phone 3a Pro priced at £449 features a 50MP 3x optical zoom camera.
- It includes a large 6.77in 120Hz FHD+ OLED screen and Qualcomm Snapdragon 7s Gen 3 processor with 12GB RAM.
- The battery offers excellent life, lasting around three days with mixed usage; it charges to 50% in 25 minutes.
- Nothing OS 3.1 (Android 15) provides a unique and customizable user experience.
- The camera is strong for its price point with the main camera producing good colors and detail, although some overprocessing occurs.

items.title: Democrats train fire on Musk as unelected billionaire dips in popularity
items.summary:
- Elon Musk claims to be eliminating waste and fraud in government during a Fox Business interview.
- Musk suggests social security and entitlement programs should be primary targets for cuts, sparking backlash from Democrats.
- House minority leader Hakeem Jeffries criticizes Musk for wanting to cut social security while profiting from government contracts.
- Democrats view Musk as a potential villain in the upcoming political landscape, especially as Trump faces challenges.
- Public polling shows only 35% of Americans view Musk positively, indicating growing unpopularity.
- Musk characterized social security as a “Ponzi scheme,” provoking grave concerns from Democrats regarding proposed cuts.
- Two federal judges mandated the rehiring of employees terminated under Musk's agency reforms, halting some of his initiatives.
- The Democratic party prepares to leverage Musk’s comments against Republicans in upcoming elections.

items.title: Otty Original Hybrid mattress review: the best hybrid mattress you can buy – and also one of the cheapest
items.summary:
- The Otty Original Hybrid is a hybrid mattress combining pocket springs with memory foam.  
- Priced under £680 for a double, it is among the most affordable bed-in-a-box hybrids.  
- Received high comfort ratings and excellent sleep quality from test users.  
- Available in multiple sizes with a trial period of 100 nights and a 10-year warranty.  
- Rated as medium firm; sinks 25mm under average weight, offering good support.  
- Made with CertiPUR- and Europur-approved materials for environmental safety.  
- Delivery costs £10 to a room of choice; fast expansion time after unboxing.

items.title: ‘Kids can bypass anything if they’re clever enough!’ How tech experts keep their children safe online
items.summary:
- Many parents feel overwhelmed and frustrated in trying to restrict their children's online activity.
- Digital parenting coach Elizabeth Milovidov emphasizes the importance of conversation and communication over strict controls.
- Experts stress the need to understand the platforms and regularly check parental control settings.
- Starting internet safety conversations early with children and empowering them is crucial.
- Technological solutions like blocking websites through the wifi router are important but not foolproof.
- Parents should balance screen time discussions with the actual content children are engaging with, as not all screen time is harmful.
- Role modeling appropriate screen usage can influence children's behavior positively.

items.title: ‘Deeply uncomfortable’: UK Starlink users switch off over Musk’s political machinations
items.summary:
- Some UK Starlink users are disconnecting due to dissatisfaction with Elon Musk's political actions.
- Barry Nisbet, among others, cites Musk’s controversial political gestures as reasons for leaving Starlink.
- Musk's influence in the US election and his political maneuvers have caused discomfort among users.
- The emergence of competitors like Eutelsat could provide alternatives to Starlink within months.
- Starlink's user base in the UK has grown significantly, from 13,000 to 87,000 subscribers in three years.
- Starlink is particularly crucial for users in remote areas with limited internet options, despite the political concerns surrounding Musk.

items.title: Virtual reality goggles helped me on the path to physical recovery
items.summary:
- The author, a 60-year-old writer, struggled with severe pain and cognitive issues due to physical injuries.
- Encountered mixed-reality headsets during an unexpected visit to a store, which suggested potential for therapeutic use.
- The experience with the virtual reality goggles alleviated pain and sparked creativity, offering a new way to engage with work prior to her upcoming surgery.
- Despite skepticism from her husband and friends about the technology’s effectiveness and cost (£3,499), she found profound hope in it.
- Overcame initial panic and ridicule regarding the use of VR, developing a newfound comfort with the technology as a means of recovery and coping.

items.title: Careless People: A Story of Where I Used to Work by Sarah Wynn-Williams review – a former disciple unfriends Facebook
items.author: Sarah Wynn-Williams
items.summary:
- The memoir details Sarah Wynn-Williams's experience working at Facebook from 2011, highlighting issues such as workaholism and exploitation.
- Wynn-Williams describes the problematic culture at Facebook, referencing institutional harassment and the ethical implications of their business practices.
- The book critiques Facebook's global impact, particularly in Myanmar, where the platform facilitated hate speech and violence.
- Wynn-Williams reflects on her naive enthusiasm for Facebook's mission and challenges the notion of 'leaning in' to work over personal well-being.
- Meta's response to the memoir labels it as outdated and false, but Wynn-Williams argues that the company's culture of carelessness remains unchanged, especially with rising AI technologies.

items.title: As cyberwarfare threat looms, cashless Nordic nations go back to banknotes
items.summary:
- In 2018, a prediction suggested Sweden would be cashless by 2025; currently, only 10% of purchases are made with cash.
- The central bank reports that Sweden and Norway have the lowest cash circulation relative to GDP globally.
- Due to rising security concerns, authorities are promoting cash usage for civil defense and emergency preparedness.
- A government inquiry recommends mandatory cash acceptance by public and private entities to ensure accessibility even during crises.
- Norway has enacted legislation to penalize retailers who refuse cash payments amid comparable security threats.

items.title: You don't need code to be a programmer. But you do need expertise
items.author: John Naughton
items.summary:
- Andrej Karpathy claims the hottest programming language is English, thanks to LLMs making coding more accessible.
- New concept of 'vibe coding' is introduced, which relies on intuition and LLM support rather than traditional coding knowledge.
- Kevin Roose shares his experience using AI to code without knowing programming languages, highlighting AI's potential but drawing criticism for lack of originality.
- Experts warn against overemphasizing AI's ability to create software, stressing the importance of human skills in programming.
- Tim O'Reilly asserts that AI will transform programming rather than replace programmers, impacting many elite professions.

items.title: How an obscure US government office has become a target of Elon Musk
items.summary:
- Elon Musk tweeted on 3 February that the GSA office 18F had been "deleted" in response to false claims about it being a far-left group.
- The tweet caused confusion at 18F, which is dedicated to improving tech services in government, with no clear communication from leadership on the implications.
- On 1 March, staff were notified of layoffs and the office's closure, reportedly influenced by high employee costs and political motivations associated with Musk's ideologies.
- 18F had created projects aimed at increasing governmental efficiency, including a free tax filing service, but faced attacks from rightwing activists misrepresenting its purpose.
- Former staffers criticized the layoffs as politically motivated and established a website to combat the narrative that 18F was aligned with partisan agendas.

items.title: From sterilising baby bottles to charging laptops, some Australians powered through Cyclone Alfred using EV batteries
Elon Musk faces week of harsh setbacks amid Tesla selloff and Doge backlash
items.summary:
- Elon Musk began the week of March 10 with a Fox Business interview discussing government efficiency and his businesses amid a significant decline in Tesla's stock.
- His net worth dropped by over $22 billion on Monday due to investor concerns regarding Tesla's value amidst trade war threats and declining profits.
- Escalating protests against Tesla and Musk's role in government have emerged, along with vandalism and social stigma against Tesla cars.
- SpaceX faced challenges, including a rocket explosion and delays in retrieving astronauts stranded in space.
- Musk's social media platform, X, suffered widespread outages attributed to a cyberattack traced back to Ukraine.
- Tensions rose over Musk's influence at Doge, culminating in a heated exchange with Secretary of State Marco Rubio and a federal judge ordering the reinstatement of thousands of workers fired by Doge.
- Polling indicated a strong public disapproval of Musk's initiatives with Doge, suggesting waning support despite his claims of popularity.
- Musk seeks to turn around Tesla's fortunes with support from Trump and the Maga world, despite ongoing backlash and new protests planned for next week.

items.title: Eggings, swastikas and dog poop: Tesla bears brunt of people’s ire against Musk
Creative Workers Share Fears and Hopes Amid AI Rise
items.author: Not given
items.summary:
- Photographer Oliver Fiegel believes generative AI tools have devastated the photography industry, making it hard for him to earn a living.
- A study showed that about 60% of jobs in advanced economies are exposed to AI, with many potentially negatively affected.
- Translator Karl Kerner feels like his profession has been diminished overnight due to AI tools impacting translation requests.
- Doctor Alexander Calvey has benefited from AI by improving efficiency in patient note-taking, allowing him to see more patients.
- Illustrator Jenny Turner has experienced a dramatic drop in commission work due to lower-priced AI-generated images, leading her to consider other employment options.

items.title: ‘I feel conflicted when I see navy recruits’: Spiro Bolos’s best phone picture
items.author: Spiro Bolos
items.summary:
- Spiro Bolos created a photo series of individuals at a train station bench in north Chicago.
- On a Sunday, he captured a photo of young navy recruits on a weekend pass, preparing to visit the city.
- Bolos reflects on the differences between his privileged students and the recruits, expressing conflict about their choices and future challenges.

items.title: Notable Tesla investor says he hopes Musk’s government role is ‘short-lived’
items.summary:
- Christopher Tsai, a major investor in Tesla, expresses hope that Elon Musk’s political role under Trump is temporary.
- Tsai notes that the stock market has reacted negatively to Musk’s involvement in politics, linking it to a decrease in Tesla's share price.
- Despite recent losses, Tsai Capital has seen significant returns since investing in Tesla, reaffirming belief in the company’s potential despite current challenges.
- A CNN poll indicates Musk's popularity has declined sharply, with 53% disapproval among Americans.
- Tsai emphasizes that he values Tesla's role as a leader in technology over traditional automotive metrics and stresses ongoing investor confidence in the company.

items.title: Free online virtual reality tool helps people tackle public speaking nerves
items.author: Dr Chris Macdonald, Dr Matteo Cella, Dr Kim Smallman
items.summary:
- A free online platform helps users practice public speaking in front of virtual audiences to reduce anxiety.
- Developed by Dr Chris Macdonald at Cambridge University, the platform incorporates exposure therapy techniques to confront fears.
- Users can practice in various VR settings, from small classrooms to stadiums of 10,000 spectators, with the option for distractions.
- A study showed that anxiety among adolescent users dropped significantly after using the VR platform.
- Future research plans include more extensive trials with control groups to better evaluate efficacy and user impact.

items.title: Apple’s UK encryption legal challenge heard behind closed doors
items.summary:
- Apple’s legal battle with the UK government regarding access to customer data was recently held behind closed doors.
- The Home Office requested access to encrypted data in Apple’s cloud servers, leading to Apple's appeal at the investigatory powers tribunal.
- UK media organizations attempted to gain entry to the hearing but were denied access due to public interest grounds.
- Apple is challenging a technology capability notice under the Investigatory Powers Act, which requires companies to help law enforcement.
- The notice sought access to Apple’s Advanced Data Protection (ADP) service, which uses end-to-end encryption.
- Apple withdrew ADP from the UK last month, maintaining it does not build backdoors in its products.
- A bipartisan group of US lawmakers urged for the hearing to be made public, expressing concerns about secrecy surrounding the UK government’s order.

items.title: How Sea Power Gained Gamer Fans Through Disco Elysium
items.author: Not given
items.summary:
- Sea Power collaborated on a soundtrack for the critically acclaimed game Disco Elysium, released in 2019.
- The game's narrative centers around an alcoholic detective, resonating with themes in Sea Power's music.
- Many songs in the game were reworked from Sea Power's previous tracks, creating an atmospheric soundscape.
- The partnership increased Sea Power's visibility and listener base, introducing them to a new audience of gamers.
- The band will perform songs from the game on an upcoming mini tour titled Soundtracks Live, catering to Disco Elysium fans.

items.title: Writers Respond to AI-Generated Short Story
items.author: Not given
items.summary:
- Writers share their reactions to a short story written by an AI model, praised for its creativity by OpenAI's CEO Sam Altman.
- Jeanette Winterson finds the AI's metafictional piece about grief to be 'beautiful and moving'.
- Nick Harkaway critiques the emptiness of AI writing and discusses copyright issues regarding AI's training data usage.
- Tracy Chevalier expresses skepticism about AI's ability to capture the essence of human creativity.
- Kamila Shamsie reflects on the potential impact of AI on writing, noting the quality of the AI story while raising concerns about copyright and creativity's future.
